title: World Liberty Financial - Trump Family Crypto Empire Worth $11.6 Billion
summary: August-September 2024: Trump family launched World Liberty Financial, a DeFi (decentralized finance) lending platform, despite Trump previously calling crypto 'a scam.' By 2025, Trump family crypto holdings reached estimated $11.6 billion (73% of net worth), with WLFI token market cap of $3.56 billion. Trumps profited $1 billion, holding $3 billion in unsold tokens. Platform built on Ethereum blockchain, offers WLFI token and USD1 stablecoin. Barron Trump identified as 'DeFi visionary.' Investments from Abu Dhabi state fund and entities with foreign ties. Senators Warren and Reed called for investigation into links to North Korea and Russia. After inauguration, administration terminated investigations into crypto firms that donated to Trump and disbanded DOJ's National Cryptocurrency Enforcement Team. Massive conflicts: president regulating industry where he has billions invested.
keyFacts: August 2024: Eric Trump announced World Liberty Financial crypto project
September 16, 2024: Debuted during two-hour livestream on X Spaces with Trump, his sons, and business partners
DeFi lending platform built on Aave protocol and Ethereum blockchain
Allows users to lend and borrow crypto without traditional financial institutions
18-year-old Barron Trump identified as the project's 'DeFi visionary'
Led by DeFi builders Chase Herro and Zak Folkman, along with Trump family members
Two main products: WLFI token and USD1 stablecoin
October 2025: WLFI token market cap reached $3.56 billion, 43rd largest cryptocurrency
March 2025: Launched USD1 stablecoin and World Liberty Markets lending platform
December 2025: Trumps profited $1 billion on proceeds, holding $3 billion in unsold tokens
Trump family crypto holdings estimated at $11.6 billion (73% of total net worth)
Total crypto income exceeded $800 million, eclipsing traditional Trump businesses
Investments from Abu Dhabi state fund and other entities with foreign ties
Senators Elizabeth Warren and Jack Reed called for investigation into links to North Korea and Russia
After inauguration, administration terminated investigations into crypto firms that donated to Trump
DOJ's National Cryptocurrency Enforcement Team disbanded in early 2025
Massive conflicts of interest: president regulating industry where he has billions invested
Trump previously called cryptocurrency 'a scam' and 'disaster waiting to happen'
